title: The Role of Reputation and Corruption in Procurement
descriptions:
Here is a 285-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: The Role of Reputation and Corruption in Procurement

This research proposal seeks to investigate the complex relationships between reputation, corruption, and procurement outcomes in four critical sectors: defense, transportation, education, and healthcare. The project's overarching goals are to avoid waste, enhance social welfare, prevent corruption, and ensure contractor compliance in public procurement. To achieve these objectives, we propose three empirical projects that will provide novel insights into the role of reputation and corruption in procurement.

The first project examines the use of reputation in contract procurement, focusing on the impacts of vendor rating systems on contractor performance, procurement costs, corruption concerns, and new bidder entry. The second project analyzes corruption in public procurement, investigating the extent of criminal networks, the effectiveness of awarding rules against corruption, and the development of corruption detection tests. The third project explores healthcare procurement regulations, conducting a descriptive analysis of EU practices, assessing the impact of discretionary awarding rules on corruption and reputation, and evaluating outcomes in terms of patients' welfare.

By integrating these three projects, we aim to provide a comprehensive understanding of the interplay between reputation, corruption, and procurement outcomes, ultimately informing policies and practices that promote transparency, accountability, and social welfare in public procurement. The proposed research has significant implications for the development of effective procurement strategies that minimize waste, corruption, and reputational risks, while maximizing social benefits in various sectors.
